manufacturerProductDescription.media_text: Eleanor Oliphant Is Completely Fine: A Novel

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on January 24, 2024
reviews.reviewTitle: 5.0 out of 5 stars Cheers for Eleanor
reviews.reviewText: Oh, I am so sorry to say goodbye to Eleanor. She stole my heart. I was rooting for her to become "completely fine" or even better, and she did not disappoint. At first I was afraid this was going to be a predictable chick lit/romance. But no, a much deeper, complicated story, and Eleanor is one of the most courageous, complicated, and lovable heroines I've come to know since Kya from Where the Crawdads Sing. When I think of Eleanor, the phrase "odd duck" comes to mind, which is not a bad thing. I am just so glad she came to embrace that part of herself, and all her other lovable, quirky traits. This story made me laugh out loud and shed tears too. That is a rare, but wonderful thing.

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on January 19, 2024
reviews.reviewTitle: 4.0 out of 5 stars Hard book to rate...
reviews.reviewText: It’s hard for me to figure out how to rate this book, probably because it’s so far from my typical choice of reading material.I can’t recall why I picked it up, but the narrative voice was what hooked me. Eleanor almost comes off like she has Asberger’s or something–she’s extremely articulate, and seems to have next to no concept of what’s expected of her socially. She’s also an unreliable narrator, judging others for having no social graces when in fact, she’s the one who erred. This was amusing, and I mostly just read to see what she’d say or do next, in a series of episodic events in her life tending (so it seemed) more or less toward nothing. For the first half of the book or so, she fixates upon a local front man from a band, deciding he’s the one, even though they’ve never met, and she objectively realizes that she’s not very attractive (having a burn on half of her face, though we won’t find out why for some time), while he’s gorgeous. She is undeterred, and goes about on a self-improvement scheme to make herself his equal to the best of her ability. Meanwhile, every Wednesday night she has a phone call with her Mummy, who is –somewhere, we’re not told where, but we’re led to believe it’s an institution of some kind. Mummy is very angry, and every phone call leaves Eleanor feeling awful and needing, so she believes, massive amounts of vodka, which she consumes every weekend, all weekend long.Then, unusual things begin to happen. Eleanor finds herself befriended by Raymond, the IT specialist at her workplace, almost against her will. She and Raymond encounter an elderly man who collapses in the street, and they save his life, thus bringing him and his family into their circle as well.As Eleanor’s fantasy toward the singer progresses, though, eventually she’s forced to confront reality. Spoiler alert: there’s a really disturbing attempted suicide scene, but it precipitates the second half of the book, where Eleanor learns what really happened in her past to give her the scar, and why her Mummy is the way she is. I saw most of this coming, but there’s a surprise twist about Mummy at the very end that helped explain the inconsistencies in her character that had previously really bothered me.The subject matter is dark, but it’s handled in a hopeful way.My rating: ***1/2Language: it’s there, though not overwhelmingSexual content: it’s there but mildViolence: it’s there but not gratuitousPolitical content: none that I can recall

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on February 5, 2024
reviews.reviewText: Don’t ask me about this book for the next week or might mess around and break out into tears of happiness and joy for the main character and everyone who took the time to give her the love she rightly deserved!

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on February 13, 2024
reviews.reviewTitle: 5.0 out of 5 stars very entertaining, and informative
reviews.reviewText: this highly entertaining book is also helpful to look at others around you with an eye to understand how they became who they are

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on February 6, 2024
reviews.reviewTitle: 5.0 out of 5 stars Must have book
reviews.reviewText: I lend this book feom a friend and read it last year. I do wanted read it again and ordered. You must learn the story of Eleanor!

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on January 13, 2024
reviews.reviewText: Kind of a slow read but gives you feel good vibes at the end. Very cute book, took me a while to get into it.

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on February 3, 2024
reviews.reviewTitle: 5.0 out of 5 stars A must read - whether you are completely fine or not
reviews.reviewText: All I have to say is this book reinforced why i love reading! Quick easy read that goes deep and addresses the fragility of human existence and the importance of human connection

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on February 6, 2024
reviews.reviewTitle: 5.0 out of 5 stars I love Eleanor
reviews.reviewText: She’s certainly not fine but she’s so much more. What a great story. I’ll be thinking about this one for awhile.
Eleanor's voice is endearing, witty and heartbreakingly captivating. She pulled me in and kept me listening as she came into her own like a rainbow.

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United Kingdom on December 30, 2023
reviews.reviewText: This book was fantastic. I had read a lot of noise about it for a while due to all the awards it had won and it did not disappoint. I couldn't put it down. The narrative that runs through is wrote from Eleanor Oliphants point of view and at times you squirm at the way she sees the world but as the story emerges you realise just why she is the way she is. I think that's also what made me love it so much as well, as her character totally emerges throughout to get to the end where you feel proud that she's reached the place she reached and thats all you could want for her. Total must read 5 stars and you will not want to put it down once you start. Glad I chose this as my last book of 2023.

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the Netherlands on September 20, 2023
reviews.reviewText: A beautiful story about trauma, self discovery, and love.

reviews.reviewTitle: Wunderbare Charaktere, spannend erzählt, obwohl gar nicht viel passiert. Perfekt!
reviews.reviewText: Ein geregelter Job seit neun Jahren, eine eigene Wohnung, jeden Tag etwas zu essen, ein Fernseher und ein Leben ohne Höhen und Tiefen- was mehr könnte sich die dreißigjährige Eleanor Oliphant denn vom Leben wünschen?! So sieht sie das jedenfalls selbst zu Beginn eines Romans, den ich auf einer vierstündigen Zugfahrt verschlungen habe. Und doch zeigt sich nach und nach, dass so ziemlich alles fehlt oder zutiefst dysfunktional ist, was ein Leben lebenswert macht: Freunde, eine Beziehung, eine Familie.Die Rahmenhandlung ist schnell erzählt: eine Frau, die in einem Büro arbeitet, ist einigermaßen einsam und unglücklich. Im Laufe des Romans verbessert sich ihre Situation. Aber halt. Das ist es natürlich nicht, warum mich das Buch Hitze und Chaos einer vierstündigen Bahnfahrt hat vergessen lassen. Eleanor ist mit all ihren besonderen Verhaltensweisen schräg und knurrig wie Ove in "Ein Mann namens Ove". Und genauso wie in diesem Roman auch, zeigt sich langsam, was dazu geführt hat, dass sie ist, wer sie ist. Das habe ich gespannt verfolgt und dabei immer mehr ihre geradlinige, unangepasste Art zu schätzen gelernt.Insofern bin ich den Menschen ihres Umfelds gefolgt, die ebenfalls immer mehr zu ihr durchdringen, die über ihre Besonderheiten nicht nur hinwegsehen, sondern das Liebenswerte in Eleanor sehen und so dazu beitragen, dass sie sich den Problemen stellen kann, die ihr das Leben vor die Füße geworfen hat.Im Anhang des Buches beschreibt die Autorin, dass sie diesen Erstling geschrieben hat, um gerade auf die Einsamkeit jüngerer Menschen aufmerksam zu machen. Geglückt!So zeigt sich wieder: Es ist oft nicht die spektakuläre Handlung, die mich bei der Stange hält, sondern es ist die Entwicklung einer Figur und die Darstellung in guter Sprache. Nach einigen Büchern der letzten Zeit, die mir entweder zu banal oder zu intellektuell abgedreht waren, war Eleanor ideal, um mal wieder ganz in ein anderes, fiktives Leben einzutauchen. Ich kann das Buch allen empfehlen, die besondere Figuren und Lebensbetrachtungen mögen.potzblog.de
Je l'ai lu il y a longtemps mais ce livre m'a laissé un excellent souvenir, héroïne attachante et histoire rondement menée.
